text: they've stepped up Airport health checks
in Nigeria as international alarm grows
over the worst outbreak of the deadly
Ebola virus since it was discovered
nearly four decades ago with concern
that this health crisis is spinning out
of control the World Health Organization
is holding an emergency meeting it could
declare a global health emergency
imposing travel bans and border controls
on affected countries but some say more
should have been done earlier on several
occasions we have repeated that the
epidemic is far from being control and I
think today unfortunately we are very
far from controlling this most deadly
Ebola outbreak us so far affected four
countries in West Africa Guinea Sierra
Leone Liberia and now Nigeria the death
rate from the current outbreak is
estimated at 50 to 60 percent almost 900
people have died the Ebola outbreak has
even intruded on a u.s. Africa summit
this week in Washington and let me
welcome the delegations from Sierra
Leone Liberia and Guinea with whom we
are working so urgently to control the
Ebola outbreak and whose citizens are in
our thoughts and prayers today both the
American aid workers who contracted
Ebola in Liberia have now been flown
home for treatment it's reported three
Spanish missionaries in Liberia have
also now tested positive but the
Americans appear to be improving after
receiving an experimental drug the
company is trying to scale up on the
production it's difficult to produce
these particular types of antibody
cocktails and it's not at the level of
being able to mass-produce
British Airways has said its suspending
its flights to and from Sierra Leone and
Liberia for the rest of this months in
Europe in the United States the
authorities and airlines are monitoring
this outbreak closely the risk of
transmission here is said to be very low
and Ebola is containable but the
country's currently affected urgently
need more outside help to prevent this
becoming an even bigger crisis in the
region
Nick childs BBC News
